Topic.Title: Alibaba Growth screaming ahead - bashers out in full force

Message.Msg: During the conference call, Marissa showed a chart that compared graphs of 2012 impressions with 2013 impressions. During all of 2012, the trend was down and pretty significantly at the end of 2012. In 2013, the chart started where it left off in December 2012 and began to climb through July where it has crossed over last year's number. Her plan was to.... 1. Get great employees 2. Build great products 3. Increase customers and usage 4. Revenue will come next The first three are well on their way. Second half of this year should show better revenue. She indicated that their video campaigns are sold out 3 months early, and that they don't have enough video inventory. This is definitely hurting Yahoo. That's why they wanted to buy DailyMotion. Their SCREEN is not delivering enough impressions. With unique content, purchased content and UGC, Yahoo believe they can add inventory to growth the business. My question would be this... Lot's of people don't believe Yahoo can turn the core business around. And that core business is not really valued at anything. However, Marissa has proven she is tackling one initiative at a time pretty successfully. What value would you give the core business if it does in fact turn around? If they show growth of the core, will you start to value it higher, or will the old Yahoo never be given much value regardless of what they do to grow it?

Message.Title: Reuters Article - Upgrades
Message.Msg: (Reuters) - Yahoo Inc's lackluster results failed to put off Wall Street analysts, who focused on the growth prospects of its investment in Chinese e-commerce firm Alibaba and Chief Executive Marissa Mayer's focus on product development. Yahoo's shares were set to open about 1.7 percent higher at around $27.35 after at least six brokerages raised their price targets on the stock even after the company trimmed its revenue forecast on Tuesday. Barclays Equity Research, Stifel Nicolaus, JPMorgan Equity Research, Evercore Partners, RBC Capital Markets and Topeka Capital raised their price targets on Yahoo's stock by as much as $8, with a top price of $34. Several analysts noted that while Yahoo's core business grew only moderately in the first quarter, revenue at 24-percent-owned Alibaba increased by 71 percent to $1.4 billion. Several brokerages raised their valuation on Alibaba, which is widely expected to go public later this year, to as much as $120 billion, higher than the $100 billion valuation put on Facebook Inc before its IPO. Evercore, which raised its valuation to $120 billion Alibaba, previously valued the company at $90 billion. Yahoo has a market capitalization of about $29 billion. Yahoo trimmed its full-year revenue forecast to $4.45-$4.55 billion from $4.5-$4.6 billion. Revenue fell slightly to $1.07 billion in the second quarter. "We think investors should give the management team the benefit of the doubt as it is unrealistic to expect a turnaround of such a challenged business in 12 months," Bernstein Research analyst Carlos Kirjner said in a note, referring to Mayer's appointment last July. Yahoo, in a live stream event akin to a TV newscast with Mayer and CFO Ken Goldman playing news anchors, acknowledged that there was pressure on prices but said Yahoo was developing new ad formats and technology that would reverse the trend. Mayer highlighted four business areas -- search, mobile, display and video -- that she said would drive revenue growth. "Wit

Message.Title: Next Potential Takeover Target
Message.Msg: Massive consolidation is beginning to occur in the cable TV industry and many cable TV operators are now the subject of M&A speculation. During the last big wave of cable TV consolidation in 2006, the operators were the first stocks to rally, but the focus then shifted to cable TV technology vendors. Seachange (SEAC) was the subject of a Brean Capital analyst note in December that said "Because of SEAC's leading position in key areas of MSO investment, it is not likely to remain an independent company in an industry consolidation scenario." SEAC has been rapidly rising in recent days, now that the wave of industry consolidation is here. SEAC soared past its 52-week high of $12.10 on Monday and set a new 52-week high yesterday of $12.50 where it has an enterprise value/revenue ratio of 1.89. In 2006, SEAC was also the subject of takeover speculation - but in every story about SEAC in 2006, its rival CCUR was also mentioned as a takeover target. CCUR recently surpassed SEAC to capture the #1 largest video on demand (VOD) technology market share, and CCUR now leads other key areas of MSO investment like start-over/look-back, Big Data Analytics, and multi-screen/CDN solutions. If you look at the reasons Brean calls SEAC a takeover target - CCUR fits all of the same criteria, and CCUR is very undervalued compared to SEAC, with CCUR trading with an enterprise value/revenue ratio of only 0.71. For CCUR to match SEAC's enterprise value/revenue ratio of 1.89, CCUR needs to rise to $16.21 per share! Look for CCUR to rally big in the weeks ahead, and for CCUR to rise above SEAC's share price in August. CCUR's year-end results/10-K filing is due out next month and its non-GAAP EPS for fiscal 2013 could potentially reach $0.50, exceeding SEAC's current trailing non-GAAP EPS of $0.44. CCUR recently increased its dividend by 100%, and now pays a huge cash dividend yield of 6.2%, the highest in the industry! CCUR would likely attract a much larger premium than SEAC.

Message.Title: Alibaba's Profit Tripled in First Quarter, Yahoo Says
Message.Msg: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., a privately held Chinese e-commerce company gearing up for an initial public offering of stock, tripled its net profit in the first quarter, according to major shareholder Yahoo Inc. For the three months through March, Alibaba's earnings rose to $669 million from $220 million a year earlier, on revenue that jumped 71% to $1.38 billion, according to a slide in Yahoo's earnings presentation Tuesday. Yahoo, which owns about 24% of Alibaba, records the impact from Alibaba one quarter in arrears.

Message.Title: Did Yahoo intentionally omit Alibaba profit growth announcement from its earnings press release??
Message.Msg: Since the news about Alibaba's growth was clearly the most important of the conference call, why was it intentionally left out of the earnings press release that went out about an hour before the call, when the information about Alibaba's growth first became known during the slide show? With this 'most important' information excluded from the press announcement, the market, in the first hour in the after hours session, instead focused attention on the clearly disappointing guidance, causing an initial sell-off in the stock and giving and unfair advantage to any buyers who may have had foreknowledge about the pending Alibaba news to scoop up the discounted shares. If I missed something in the release then I stand corrected, but if not, it seems the question can clearly be asked about intentional market manipulation in the after hours session, which would merit further review. It just makes no sense for Yahoo to not have included this most important financial highlight about its Alibaba holding in its earnings press announcement, where it should have been prominently noted, with the effect of causing its shares to sell off for a good hour or so in the after hours session before the later spike. http://finance.yahoo.com/news/yahoo-reports-second-quarter-2013-200500159.html

Message.Title: Make a Fortune from Cable TV Industry Consolidation
Message.Msg: A huge wave of consolidation is beginning to take place in the cable TV industry with many cable TV operators the subject of M&A rumors. During the last wave of cable TV industry consolidation in 2006 the operators were the initial stocks to run, but afterwards the focus shifted to cable TV tech vendors. Seachange (SEAC) was the subject of a Brean Capital analyst research note this past December that said "Because of SEAC's leading position in key areas of MSO investment, it is not likely to remain an independent company in an industry consolidation scenario." SEAC has been rallying big in recent days, now that a wave of industry consolidation is here, soaring past its 52-week high of $12.10 on Monday and setting a new 52-week high yesterday of $12.50 where it trades with an enterprise value/revenue ratio of 1.89. Back in 2006, SEAC was also the subject of takeover rumors - but in every article written about SEAC in 2006, its rival CCUR was mentioned as a potential takeover target as well. Since then, CCUR has actually surpassed SEAC to capture the #1 largest video on demand (VOD) technology market share, and CCUR also leads in other key areas like start-over/look-back, and Big Data Analytics. CCUR hasn't received any analyst research notes in recent months like SEAC, but if you look at the reasons Brean calls SEAC a takeover target - CCUR fits all of the same criteria, and CCUR is extremely undervalued vs. SEAC, with CCUR currently trading with an enterprise value/revenue ratio of only 0.71. For CCUR just to match SEAC's current enterprise value/revenue ratio of 1.89, CCUR needs to rise to $16.21. Look for CCUR to explode in the weeks ahead, and for CCUR to surpass SEAC's share price next month. CCUR's 10-K filing is due out next month and CCUR's annual non-GAAP EPS could potentially reach $0.50, exceeding SEAC's current non-GAAP EPS of $0.44. CCUR recently raised its dividend by 100%, and now pays a huge dividend yield of 6.2%, the highest in the industry!

Message.Title: This stock has no way but go up - Here is the reason
Message.Msg: 1. The valuation of Alibaba is around $120 Bil - Yahoo's share is $29 Bil. Yahoo Japan is worth at least 4.5 bil. So, this adds up to 33.5 Bil. With 1 Bil Shares outstanding, this values per share at $33.50 2. YHOO is expected to earn $1.4 for the year. At P/E of 15, this values YHOO @ 21 which could go to 28 at P/E of 20 if some of Marissa's bets pay off and Yahoo starts growing again. So, the fair value is between $54.50 to $61.50. Have patience. Analysts ultimately gets it right and comes up to this value of $60 on average in the next 2 quarters. They take some time to correct their valuation, but, they get it right when the stock trades at that price. So, hold on to your stock and not watch it every day! Better yet, BUY some Jan 2015 CALLs and stash them away at a safe place.

Message.Title: Yahoo Japan at NEW 52 week high heading into earnings next week!!!!
Message.Msg: Yahoo Japan expecting huge growth in earnings going forward. See article below. Yahoo Japan Corp. (4689), operator of the country’s most-visited Web portal, expects economic growth and a consumer shift to mobile services to spur revenue gains as it targets advertising growth of at least 10 percent. “We expect to continue the growth pace a while,” Chief Financial Officer Toshiki Ohya said in an interview in Tokyo. Advertising, which account for more than half the company’s sales, rose 15 percent to 190.5 billion yen ($2 billion) in the year ended March. Yahoo Japan, 42 percent owned by billionaire Masayoshi Son’s SoftBank Corp. (9984), is targeting a 77 percent increase in earnings within six years by expanding in e-commerce and offering more services for smartphones and tablet computers. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s strategy to end deflation, nicknamed Abenomics, may stoke earnings for the web portal as advertisers boost their spending to tap economic growth.

Topic.Title: Yahoo Japan at NEW 52 week high heading into earnings next week!!!!

Message.Msg: Great point, currently the market values Yahoo core at $0. Today's rise, and the last 3 years has always been about Asian assets. Until the IPO actually comes to play, it will STILL be about the assets and not the core. My BOGUS analysis has been spot on since early 2009, showing continued decline in revenue and profits in Yahoo core, while having the Asian assets as the "insurance policy" to put a floor on the decline. Whether we believe the speculation of "maybe audited" earnings of Alibaba, and the growth of Yahoo Japan, we finally have good management, (hedge fund + CEO with vision), hedge on yen currency to protect the asian assets, lots of cash now, and potential cash from disposal of asian assets. In my opinion, today's Yahoo management will abide by the agreement to dispose half of Alibaba at IPO price (even though they admit this was a mistake), and hold onto the remainder for long term growth (more insurance to protect from further declines of core business). Also, Yahoo will find a solution to the 38% tax on the sale of these assets, thus creating more value to shareholders. Now that Softbank has finished the purchase of Sprint, maybe we will see some movement towards Yahoo's disposal of a portion of Yahoo Japan, while the stock is in maximum growth mode. Best case scenario is still a cash-rich split of these assets, maximizing shareholder value again. In either case, these two Asian companies want their assets back at the lowest possible price, but the market has moved against them substantially in the last 18 months, with no slowdown of growth with either company. Marissa still has a long road ahead of her, but she is right on one thing. IT ALL STARTS WITH PEOPLE. Surround yourself with people that are experts in what they do, that will buy your vision, and help create the momentum needed to weather the storm. Belief in growing your company is half the battle. Getting others to believe is the second half. Good luck to you, whether short or long.

Topic.Title: Yahoo Japan at NEW 52 week high heading into earnings next week!!!!

Message.Msg: if the last 3 years has always been about Asian assets.,why yhoo stock only worth $15 a year ago and today is $29.5 ? Alibaba is a privately owned company, they do not have to compliant with any standard accounting practices, thus revenues or earning reports cannot be confirmed, or validated. Baidu, Sohu and other Chinese public traded companies are over-inflated by US standard. If Alibaba is a public traded company, their e/r will be scrutinized and questioned.. for now, Yhoo is reporting Alibaba's income triple as a face value to buy time for domestic declining ads revenues. The fact of the matter is Yhoo's revs missed the expectations, income beats were mainly due to huge write off some of the M&A, laid off and aggressive cost cutting activities. Even if Alibaba announces IPO tomorrow, and YHOO get a huge lump sum of cash, their business models won't accelerate revenues in foreseeable future. I already cashed out my long position today.. keep my power dry awaiting for pull back.. GL

Message.Msg: There were plenty of bullish views, but it would appear the goodwill extended the company had little to do with the fledgling turnaround in Yahoo!’s main business and a lot more to do with its revenue reported from its 24% ownership stake in the privately held Chinese e-commerce company Alibaba Group Holdings, and its 35% share in Yahoo!
